item.title: Another Battle Royale Game Is Shutting Down For Good
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

In April 2022, developer and publisher Sharkmob officially launched Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodhunt, a battle royale set in White Wolf Publishing's World of Darkness. Players took control of vampires in Prague as they joined rival sects and battled each other with their supernatural abilities and conventional weapons. However, new updates for the game ceased in 2023, and now Bloodhunt's servers are going offline in 2026.

Sharkmob announced the news on its site that Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodhunt will have its final death on April 28, 2026. Once the game's servers go offline, the PC and PlayStation 5 versions of this title will no longer be playable.

In a message addressed to the Bloodhunt community, Sharkmob shared its gratitude for the game's four-year run.

"When we first opened the streets of Prague to you, we could only hope that the nights you spent there would create the memories they did," reads the statement. "From the battles fought on the rooftops to the friendships made in the chaos, Bloodhunt has lived through you in countless unforgettable ways. During these past four years, we have been thrilled to see your passion and dedication to Bloodhunt ... However, despite you, our amazing community, the current player population has reached a level where keeping the servers running is no longer sustainable. This has led us to make the difficult decision to take Bloodhunt offline."

Token purchases have already been disabled, but the in-game store will remain open so players can use the tokens they already have before the game goes offline.

Earlier this month, the action-RPG Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines 2 hit PS5, Xbox Series X|S, and PC. There was a 21-year gap between this game and its predecessor, Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Star Wars: Unlimited TCG Gets Its Own Pokemon Battle Academy-Style Intro Game
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Asmodee has taken a page out of the Pokemon playbook with its latest addition to the Star Wars: Unlimited TCG catalog. Intro Battle Hoth is a standalone experience geared toward new players of the official Star Wars trading card game. It's very similar in concept to Pokemon TCG: Battle Academy and Disney Lorcana: Gateway. The fast-paced spin on Star Wars: Unlimited is available now for $20. As an added bonus, the game is themed around the Battle of Hoth from The Empire Strikes Back.

Star Wars: Unlimited TCG - Intro Battle Hoth

$20

Intro Battle Hoth is a head-to-head game for two players that takes roughly 20 minutes to play. Asmodee recommends Star Wars: Unlimited for players ages 12 and up.

The $20 "New Player Game" comes with two pre-built, 50-card decks. Princess Leia and the Rebel forces must defend Echo Base from Darth Vader and his Imperial Army. Much like Pokemon Battle Academy, Intro Battle Hoth comes with an illustrated game board with labeled spots for cards.

There's also a full rulebook and all accessories needed to play. Here's the full list of contents inside the box:

  • 104 Cards
    • Princess Leia's Rebel Forces Deck
    • Darth Vader's Imperial Army Deck
  • Game Board
  • 57 Damage Counters
  • 2 Epic Action Counters
  • 1 Initiative Counter
  • 1 Rulebook
  • 1 Info Sheet

Star Wars: Unlimited TCG Boxes, Boosters, Decks

Star Wars: Unlimited TCG debuted in March 2024 with a 252-card set called Spark of Rebellion. Asmodee has since released four more sets, and the next one, Secrets of Power, is slated for November 7. The prolific card/board game manufacturer has already confirmed three Star Wars: Unlimited TCG sets for 2026: A Lawless Time, Ashes of the Empire, and. Homeworlds.

If you're interested in collecting Star Wars: Unlimited cards, we've rounded up the Booster Boxes, Prerelease Boxes, Spotlight Decks, and Starter Sets you can buy now below.

Browse by category:

  • Starter Sets
  • Spotlight Decks
  • Prerelease Boxes
  • 2025 Gift Box
  • Booster Boxes
  • Booster Packs
  • Carbonite Booster Boxes

Star Wars: Unlimited Starter Sets

The first three Star Wars: Unlimited sets had $35 Starter Sets with two pre-built decks.

Each Starter Set comes with two 50-card decks--10 of the cards are exclusive--and deck boxes with character art of the named leaders. The Starter Sets also come with a quickstart rules guide and various damage counters.

  • Shadows of the Galaxy: Moff Gideon / The Mandalorian -- $31.81 ($35)
  • Twilight of the Republic: Ahsoka / General Grevious -- $35
  • Spark of Rebellion: Luke Skywalker / Darth Vader -- Sold out

Star Wars: Unlimited Spotlight Decks

Asmodee ditched the Starter Sets for a pair of individual decks called Spotlight Decks in 2025.

Each Spotlight Deck comes with a 50-card deck--four of the cards are exclusive--and a booster pack with 16 cards. It's worth noting that the 50-card decks include some cards from previous sets. Each deck has a named leader

  • Legends of the Force
    • Darth Maul -- $25
    • Qui-Gon Jinn -- $25
  • Jump to Lightspeed
    • Han Solo -- $24
    • Boba Fett -- $28

Star Wars: Unlimited Spotlight Deck Displays

Spotlight Decks are also available in 6-packs. These are mainly designed for tournament play and for larger groups of friends, since you get three of each Spotlight Deck in the carton.

  • Secrets of Power -- $150 | November 7
    • 3 Padme Amidala Decks
    • 3 Chancellor Palpatine Decks
  • Legends of the Force -- $140 ($150)
    • 3 Darth Maul Decks
    • 3 Qui-Gon Jinn Decks
  • Jump to Lightspeed -- $117.49 ($150)
    • 3 Han Solo Decks
    • 3 Boba Fett Decks

Star Wars: Unlimited Booster Boxes

Booster Boxes come with 24 packs featuring 16 cards each for a total of 384 cards. Booster Packs retail for $6 each, so Booster Boxes net you four packs free at MSRP. That said, most of the Booster Boxes sell for around $90, which breaks down to less than $4/pack. The 2025 Booster Boxes are the cheapest right now, with Jump to Lightspeed sitting at $73 and Legends of the Force at $88. If you want the original Spark of Rebellion set, the Booster Box for $91 is the way to go.

Each Star Wars: Unlimited Booster Pack comes with: 9 common cards, 3 uncommon cards, 1 rare or legendary card, 1 leader, 1 base/token, and 1 foil card.

  • Legends of the Force (24 Packs) -- $88 ($120)
  • Jump to Lightspeed (24 Packs) -- $73 ($120)
  • Twilight of the Republic (24 Packs) -- $92 ($120)
  • Shadows of the Galaxy (24 Packs) -- $91.67 ($120)
  • Spark of Rebellion (24 Packs) -- $91 ($120)

Star Wars: Unlimited Booster Packs

  • Jump to Lightspeed -- $6
  • Shadows of the Galaxy -- $6.90
  • Spark of Rebellion -- $12.40

Star Wars: Unlimited Prerelease Boxes

Despite the moniker "Prerelease Box," these aren't exclusive, limited-time bundles. The Prerelease Box is essentially the Elite Trainer Box or MTG Bundle, albeit on a smaller (and cheaper) scale. Each Prerelease Box comes with six Booster Packs with 16 cards in each pack. You'll also get two exclusive promo codes for the Rebel and Empire leaders in the set. Along with the cards, Prerelease Boxes come with damage counters and a quickstart guide.

  • Legends of the Force -- $25 ($30)
  • Jump to Lightspeed -- $28 ($30)
  • Twilight of the Republic -- $30
  • Shadows of the Galaxy -- $38.50
  • Spark of Rebellion -- Sold out

Star Wars: Unlimited 2025 Gift Box

On November 5, Asmodee is releasing a 2025 Gift Box for Star Wars: Unlimited. It's not available to preorder at Amazon, but you can secure one from Walmart. The Gift Box is $30 and includes eight Booster Packs, two exclusive variant cards, and an oversized leader card. You'll get two Boosters from each of the following sets: Secrets of Power, Legends of the Force, Jump to Lightspeed, Twilight of the Republic.

item.title: DayZ Dev Slams Valve For Using Gambling Mechanics In Games
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Aside from its massive success with Steam, Valve has also benefited from the longevity of Counter-Strike and Counter-Strike 2, which fueled massive in-game marketplaces. However, Dean Hall--the creator of DayZ and Icarus--believes that Valve should be taken to task for using gambling mechanics like loot boxes to monetize Counter-Strike 2.

"It's something I think Valve does not get anywhere near enough criticism about," Hall told Eurogamer. "I'm honestly disgusted with gambling mechanics in video games at all--they have absolutely no place. My challenge to game developers is that if they think these things are not a problem, they make the data available to universities who are crying out to study this stuff."

Loot boxes have largely fallen out of favor in the industry, especially after many attempts to legislate or ban them entirely. In Counter-Strike 2, loot boxes can contain desirable objects like weapon or armor skins that can be traded or resold for real money. But there is often no guarantee that the loot boxes contain the items players want. If players are spending real money to purchase loot boxes over and over again to find what they're looking for, it could be considered a form of gambling.

Earlier this year, Activision's Overwatch 2 restored loot boxes to the franchise, but with changes to increase transparency of how the loot boxes work, as well as offering a guarantee that an item of Rare or better quality can be found in every loot box. Activision's Heathstone helped usher in the age of loot boxes in 2014, and suffered a backlash because of it.

Last week, Valve updated the original Counter-Strike, which tanked the in-game re-seller market for weapons, and reportedly wiped out roughly $1.75 billion in value from sellers. Outside of the game, a planned fan-remake of Counter-Strike, Counter-Strike: Legacy, has reportedly run into some trouble with Valve, and may be shut down.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/dayz-dev-slams-valve-for-using-gambling-mechanics-in-games/1100-6535751/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
